Yes, the Saxon people encountered resistance from their own tribes and communities when it came to adopting cultural practices from other societies. The Saxons were known for their fiercely independent and tribalistic ways, which often led to conflict and resistance against outside influences.

One of the most significant instances of resistance was towards the Saxon conversion to Christianity. Many Saxon tribes and leaders resisted the adoption of Christianity, as it challenged their traditional pagan beliefs and ways of life. It took several generations for Christianity to become the dominant religion in Saxon society.

Saxon leaders sometimes faced opposition from their own people when they adopted practices from neighboring societies. For example, some Saxon leaders who adopted Roman practices faced opposition from their own people, who viewed these practices as foreign and not aligned with Saxon values.

The Saxon people coped with this resistance in different ways. In some cases, they found ways to adapt the new practices to their own values and traditions, forging a new cultural synthesis. In other cases, they simply accepted the resistance and continued to uphold their traditional ways of life.

Overall, while the Saxons were open to adopting new practices from other societies, they also faced significant resistance from within their own tribes and communities. The Saxon people coped with this resistance through an ongoing negotiation and balancing act between their own traditions and the new ideas and practices from other cultures.
